title: Narrative Writing — Setting and Atmosphere
description: Students learn to craft vivid settings that establish atmosphere in narrative writing. They study how published authors use sensory details, figurative language, and word choice to transport readers to another time and place.
instructions:
1. Define setting: time, place, and conditions of a story.
2. Discuss how setting creates atmosphere (mood).
3. Analyze setting passages from books read this quarter.
4. Identify sensory details: sight, sound, smell, touch, taste.
5. Practice writing setting descriptions using all five senses.
6. Introduce figurative language: simile, metaphor, personification.
7. Students write a medieval setting description using all techniques.
8. Peer review for vivid, immersive quality.

slides.heading: Narrative Setting
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: "Narrative Setting." Think of "narrative" as just a fancy word for a story. So, we're talking about how to describe the *setting* of a story, which is basically where and when it happens. The subtitle tells us the really cool part: how setting helps create "atmosphere," which is the feeling or mood of the story.

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. Have books from this quarter handy for finding setting examples.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we're getting our supplies ready! You'll need your language notebook to write in, and a pencil. The "books for setting examples" means the books we've been reading in class – we'll use those to see how good authors describe places. Colored pencils are for drawing, and the "figurative language reference" is like a cheat sheet for cool word tricks we'll learn. Go grab those now so you're all set!

slides.text: Setting is more than a backdrop — it creates ATMOSPHERE. A dark, stormy night feels different from a sunny meadow. Good writers use setting to make readers FEEL the story before anything happens. Today you learn to paint with words.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about understanding what "setting" really means in a story. It's not just *where* the story happens, but also *when* and even the general vibe, like if it's sunny or stormy. The slide reminds us that a good setting can make you *feel* things, like excitement or fear, even before the main action starts. Today, we're going to learn how to use our words to create those feelings, just like an artist uses paint.

slides.text: Sensory details engage all five senses: SIGHT (the flickering torchlight cast dancing shadows), SOUND (the clash of swords echoed through the stone corridor), SMELL (woodsmoke and roasting meat drifted from the great hall), TOUCH (the rough wool tunic scratched against her skin), TASTE (the ale was bitter and warm). Use at least 3 senses in every setting description.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're diving into "sensory details," which is a super important way to make your writing come alive. It means using words that appeal to our five senses: what we can see, hear, smell, touch, and even taste. The examples on the slide show how you can describe a castle with flickering lights, the sound of swords, the smell of smoke, the feel of rough cloth, or the taste of ale. Remember to try and use at least three of these senses in every description you write.

slides.text: Figurative language adds power: SIMILE (the castle loomed like a sleeping giant), METAPHOR (the fog was a gray blanket over the village), PERSONIFICATION (the wind whispered secrets through the arrow slits). These tools transform ordinary descriptions into memorable, vivid images.
slides.mascot_explanation: This next step introduces "figurative language," which is like adding superpowers to your descriptions! We're looking at three cool tools: similes, which compare two things using "like" or "as" (like a castle being *like* a sleeping giant), metaphors, which say one thing *is* another (like fog *being* a blanket), and personification, where you give human qualities to non-human things (like the wind *whispering*). These make your writing way more interesting and memorable for the reader.

slides.text: Word choice matters: 'The castle was big and old' vs. 'The crumbling fortress towered above the misty valley, its ancient stones scarred by centuries of siege.' Same idea, but specific, evocative words create a completely different experience for the reader.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about picking the *best* words. You can say a castle was "big and old," but that's kind of boring, right? The slide shows a much better example: "The crumbling fortress towered above the misty valley, its ancient stones scarred by centuries of siege." See how using words like "crumbling," "towered," "misty," and "scarred" creates a much stronger picture and feeling? Choosing strong, specific words makes your writing much more powerful.

slides.prompt: Write two setting descriptions (each 8-10 sentences): (1) A medieval marketplace at midday — bustling, loud, colorful, alive with activity. (2) The same marketplace at midnight — empty, eerie, mysterious. Use at least 4 sensory details and 2 figurative language devices in each. Notice how the SAME place can have completely different atmospheres depending on how you describe it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to put it all together! You're going to write two descriptions of a medieval marketplace. First, imagine it super busy and noisy in the daytime, and then imagine the exact same place at midnight, all quiet and spooky. For each one, try to use at least four senses and two of those figurative language tricks we just learned. This will really show you how changing the details can completely change the feeling, or atmosphere, of a place.

slides.text: Setting is one of the most powerful tools in a writer's toolkit. Master it, and you can transport your reader anywhere — a medieval castle, a distant planet, or the bottom of the ocean. The secret is specific, sensory, figurative language.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write vivid setting descriptions using sensory details and figurative language to create distinct atmospheres?
slides.mascot_explanation: We've reached the end of our lesson, and you've learned something awesome! Setting isn't just a background; it's a powerful way to pull your reader into the story and make them feel exactly what you want them to feel. By using all those sensory details and figurative language tricks, you can describe any place imaginable and make it feel real. The most important thing is to be specific and use vivid language to create a strong atmosphere.

parent_notes: Setting description is a foundational narrative skill. The comparison exercise (same place, different times) teaches that atmosphere comes from the WRITER's choices, not just the physical location. Encourage your child to notice settings in everything they read. When reading aloud together, pause occasionally to appreciate how an author establishes setting. Figurative language (simile, metaphor, personification) will be developed further in narrative writing lessons.

title: Multiplying Fractions — Conceptual Understanding
description: Students learn to multiply fractions using area models and number lines before moving to the algorithm. They discover that multiplying by a fraction less than 1 produces a SMALLER result, challenging the common misconception that multiplication always makes things bigger.
instructions:
1. Present the puzzle: What is 1/2 of 1/2? Use a picture to show it equals 1/4.
2. Multiplication as 'of': 1/3 × 1/2 means 1/3 OF 1/2.
3. Area model: draw a rectangle, divide one way for the first fraction, the other way for the second.
4. State the algorithm: multiply numerators, multiply denominators.
5. Practice with simple fractions.
6. Discuss: Why is the product SMALLER than either factor?
7. Multiply whole numbers by fractions.
8. Word problems with fraction multiplication.

slides.heading: Multiplying Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: multiplying fractions! It sounds tricky, but we're going to break it down step-by-step so it makes total sense. We'll learn how to figure out problems like "what is half of a half?" and see how multiplying by a fraction can actually make a number smaller, which is different from what we usually think about multiplication.

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. Have graph paper and colored pencils ready for area model drawings.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need to get our supplies ready. You'll need your math notebook to write things down, a pencil for drawing and writing, colored pencils to make our drawings pop, graph paper which has those neat little squares that are perfect for drawing shapes, and a ruler to make sure our lines are straight. Go grab all those things, and make sure your notebook is open and the graph paper and colored pencils are easy to reach.

slides.text: Here is a puzzle: 1/2 × 1/2 = ? Draw a square. Shade half of it. Now shade half OF that half in a different color. The overlap is 1/4 of the whole square. So 1/2 × 1/2 = 1/4. Multiplication by a fraction LESS than 1 makes things SMALLER. This is different from whole number multiplication!
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like solving a cool puzzle! We want to figure out what "half of a half" is. Imagine a square; first, shade in exactly half of it. Now, take one of your colored pencils and shade in half of the *already shaded* part. See how the part that's colored in with *both* colors is just a small piece of the whole square? That small piece is 1/4 of the whole thing, showing that 1/2 times 1/2 equals 1/4.

slides.text: Area model method: To find 1/3 × 1/2, draw a rectangle. Divide it into 2 equal COLUMNS (for 1/2). Shade 1 column. Now divide the rectangle into 3 equal ROWS (for 1/3). The overlap of 1 shaded column and 1 row gives 1 small rectangle out of 6 total. So 1/3 × 1/2 = 1/6.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to use a drawing trick called an area model to figure out 1/3 of 1/2. Grab your ruler and draw a rectangle. First, divide it into two equal columns and shade one of them – that shows the 1/2. Then, divide the *whole* rectangle into three equal rows, and your shaded column will now be split into little sections. The part that's overlapped by the shading and the row divisions is your answer, and you'll see it's 1/6 of the whole rectangle.

slides.text: The algorithm is simple: multiply the numerators together, multiply the denominators together. 1/3 × 1/2 = (1×1)/(3×2) = 1/6. Another example: 2/3 × 3/4 = (2×3)/(3×4) = 6/12 = 1/2. Always simplify the result.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us the shortcut for multiplying fractions, called the algorithm. It's super simple: you just multiply the top numbers (the numerators) straight across, and then multiply the bottom numbers (the denominators) straight across. So, for 1/3 times 1/2, you do 1 times 1 on top and 3 times 2 on the bottom, which gives you 1/6. If you get a fraction that can be simplified, like 6/12, always make sure to reduce it to its simplest form, which is 1/2.

slides.text: Multiplying a whole number by a fraction: 'What is 3/4 of 20?' means 3/4 × 20 = (3×20)/4 = 60/4 = 15. This makes sense: 1/4 of 20 is 5, so 3/4 of 20 is 15. Check: is 15 less than 20? Yes, because we took 3/4 of it, not all of it.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is how we multiply a whole number by a fraction, like figuring out "3/4 of 20." Think of it as breaking the whole number into equal parts based on the bottom number of the fraction. So, to find 3/4 of 20, you first find what 1/4 of 20 is, which is 5. Then, since you need 3/4, you just multiply that 5 by 3, which gives you 15. It makes sense because 15 is less than the original 20, since we only took a *part* of it.

slides.prompt: Solve with area models AND the algorithm: (1) 1/2 × 1/3 (2) 2/3 × 3/5 (3) 3/4 × 2/3 (4) 1/4 × 4/5 (5) 5/6 × 3/10. Then: (6) 2/3 of 24 (7) 3/4 of 60 (8) 5/8 of 40. Word problems: (9) A recipe calls for 3/4 cup sugar. You want to make 1/2 the recipe. How much sugar? (10) A garden is 2/3 of an acre. You plant flowers in 1/4 of the garden. What fraction of an acre has flowers?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to put everything we've learned into practice! You'll use both the area model drawings and the fraction algorithm to solve the first five problems, which are all about multiplying fractions. Then, for problems 6, 7, and 8, you'll practice multiplying whole numbers by fractions, just like we did on the last slide. Finally, tackle the word problems to see how these math skills work in real-life situations – you've got this!

slides.text: Multiplying fractions is actually easier than adding them — no common denominator needed! The key insight is that multiplying by a fraction less than 1 gives a SMALLER result. This makes sense: 1/2 of something is always less than the whole thing.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student multiply fractions using both area models and the algorithm, and understand why the product is smaller than either factor?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did a fantastic job working through all those fraction multiplication problems! We learned that multiplying fractions is actually pretty straightforward, and the coolest part is understanding *why* multiplying by a fraction less than 1 always gives you a smaller answer. You can now confidently multiply fractions using both drawings and the algorithm, and you get why it makes sense!

parent_notes: Fraction multiplication is conceptually counterintuitive — children expect multiplication to make things bigger. The area model is crucial for building understanding. The word 'of' translates to multiplication: '1/3 of 1/2' means 1/3 × 1/2. This connection helps with word problems. The algorithm (multiply straight across) is simple, but make sure conceptual understanding comes first. Cooking contexts work perfectly: making half a recipe that calls for 2/3 cup means 1/2 × 2/3 = 1/3 cup.

title: The Crusades — Causes and the First Crusade
description: Students learn about the complex causes of the Crusades and the events of the First Crusade (1096-1099). They analyze multiple motivations — religious, political, and economic — and begin to understand the Crusades as a pivotal series of events with lasting consequences.
instructions:
1. Set the context: by the late 1000s, Muslim forces controlled the Holy Land.
2. Pope Urban II's call to arms at Clermont (1095).
3. Multiple motivations: religious devotion, political ambition, economic opportunity, adventure.
4. The People's Crusade — poorly organized, mostly disastrous.
5. The First Crusade — better organized, captured Jerusalem in 1099.
6. Discuss multiple perspectives: Christian, Muslim, Byzantine, Jewish.
7. Map the routes of the First Crusade.
8. Analyze: Were the Crusades justified? Consider multiple viewpoints.
materials_needed: Map of Mediterranean and Middle East

slides.heading: The Crusades
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of a book, introducing us to the topic: The Crusades, and specifically focusing on what made them happen and the very first one. It's basically setting the stage for a big, important story in history.

slides.setup_instructions: Open history notebook. Have a map of the Eastern Mediterranean ready. This is complex history with multiple perspectives.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need to gather our tools! We've got a history notebook to jot down important stuff, colored pencils to make our notes pop, a map so we can see where all this action happens, a regular pencil for writing, and a timeline to keep track of when things happened. Go grab these with a grown-up's help so we're ready to dive in!

slides.text: In 1095, Pope Urban II gave a speech that changed history. He called on European Christians to travel to the Holy Land (modern Israel/Palestine) and recapture Jerusalem from Muslim control. His reasons: religious duty, uniting quarreling European lords, and aiding the Byzantine emperor. The response was overwhelming — thousands took up the cross.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about a really important speech given by Pope Urban II back in 1095. Imagine him telling a huge crowd that they needed to go on a journey to a special place called the Holy Land to take it back from Muslim control. He had a few reasons for this, like religious duty and helping out a friend, and tons of people decided to go!

slides.text: But motivations were complex: RELIGIOUS — genuine belief in the spiritual merit of pilgrimage and holy war. POLITICAL — kings and lords sought power and land. ECONOMIC — merchants saw new trade opportunities. PERSONAL — younger sons with no inheritance sought fortune. ADVENTURE — the excitement of travel in an era when most people never left their village.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, while the Pope had his reasons, people who actually went on the Crusades had all sorts of different motivations, like a mix of things. Some were super religious and truly believed it was the right thing to do, others were looking for power or land, some saw it as a chance to get rich through trade, and a few were just looking for excitement and adventure!

slides.text: The First Crusade (1096-1099): After a disastrous 'People's Crusade' of untrained peasants (most perished), organized armies of European knights marched through Byzantine territory, through modern Turkey, and besieged Antioch and then Jerusalem. In July 1099, they captured Jerusalem in a brutal assault. Crusader states were established along the coast.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide walks us through what actually happened during the first Crusade. After a rough start with a group of untrained people, a more organized army of knights marched a long way, facing tough battles, and eventually captured the city of Jerusalem. They even set up their own kingdoms along the coast after that!

slides.text: Multiple perspectives matter: To European Christians, the Crusades were a holy mission. To Muslims, they were an aggressive invasion of their lands. To the Byzantine emperor, they were supposed to be HELP but became a threat. To Jewish communities in Europe and the Middle East, the Crusades brought horrific violence. No single narrative tells the whole truth.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's super important to remember that not everyone saw the Crusades the same way. For Christians in Europe, it was a holy mission, but for Muslims, it felt like an invasion, and for Jewish people, it sadly brought a lot of violence and suffering. Understanding this means looking at it from everyone's point of view, not just one side.

slides.prompt: Create a multi-perspective analysis: (1) Map the route of the First Crusade from France to Jerusalem. (2) Write 4 short diary entries — one from each perspective: a European knight, a Muslim defender, a Byzantine citizen, a Jewish merchant. Each should describe the same events from their viewpoint. (3) Write a paragraph: Why do historians say the Crusades had 'mixed motivations'?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to get creative! We're going to map out the path the first Crusaders took from Europe all the way to Jerusalem. Then, you'll write four short diary entries from the perspective of a knight, a Muslim defender, a Byzantine person, and a Jewish merchant, describing the same event differently. Finally, think about why historians say there were many different reasons for the Crusades happening.

slides.text: The Crusades are one of history's most complex events. They were motivated by faith, greed, politics, and adventure all at once. Understanding them requires hearing multiple voices and resisting simple narratives of heroes and villains.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student explain multiple causes of the Crusades, describe the First Crusade, and analyze events from multiple perspectives?
slides.mascot_explanation: We just finished a deep dive into the Crusades! You learned that they weren't just about one thing – people had all sorts of reasons for going, from faith to wanting power to just seeking adventure. You also got to see how different people experienced these events, which is a really important way to understand history.

parent_notes: The Crusades are sensitive material that should be presented with balance and nuance. Avoid portraying either side as wholly good or evil — both Christians and Muslims committed atrocities and acts of courage. The multi-perspective diary activity develops empathy and critical thinking. This connects to the Islamic Golden Age lesson from week 11, showing that the Muslim world was highly civilized when Europeans invaded. The lasting consequences of the Crusades (trade, cultural exchange, ongoing tensions) will be explored next week.

title: Economic Geography — Natural Resources and Industry
description: Students explore how natural resources shape economic activity around the world. They learn about renewable and nonrenewable resources, map major resource-producing regions, and analyze how resource distribution affects wealth and power.
instructions:
1. Define natural resources: materials from the Earth that people use.
2. Renewable vs. nonrenewable resources.
3. Major resource categories: minerals, fossil fuels, water, forests, soil.
4. Map where key resources are found: oil (Middle East, Russia), minerals (Africa, Australia).
5. Discuss how resources shape economies: oil-rich nations, mining economies.
6. The 'resource curse': why resource-rich countries are not always wealthy.
7. Students create an economic resource map.
8. Discuss sustainability: Can we use resources without depleting them?

slides.heading: Economic Geography
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey! This first slide is just introducing what we're going to talk about: how the stuff we dig out of the ground or grow, called natural resources, really shapes how countries make money and do business. Think about places that have lots of oil or big forests – that makes them really important in the world!

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. Have a blank world map ready for creating an economic resource map.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is telling us what supplies we need for our activity. You'll need your geography notebook to write things down, colored pencils to make our map colorful and clear, a world map to draw on, an atlas or just a good reference book to look up where things are, and a regular pencil for writing. Go grab those now!

slides.text: Natural resources are materials from the Earth that humans use: minerals, fossil fuels, water, soil, forests, and sunlight. They are not evenly distributed — some countries are resource-rich while others have very few. This uneven distribution shapes global economics, politics, and even wars.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about defining what natural resources are. Basically, they're anything from the Earth that we use – like metals, oil, water, or even the dirt we grow food in. The big idea here is that these resources aren't spread out evenly everywhere, and that's a huge reason why some countries are super rich and powerful, and others aren't.

slides.text: RENEWABLE resources can be replenished: solar energy, wind, water (through the water cycle), forests (if managed sustainably), soil (if cared for). NONRENEWABLE resources exist in fixed amounts and will eventually run out: fossil fuels (oil, coal, natural gas), minerals (gold, iron, copper, rare earth elements). Our economy depends heavily on nonrenewable resources.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at two main types of resources: renewable and nonrenewable. Renewable ones, like sunshine or wind, can basically be used over and over without running out, or they grow back, like trees if we're careful. Nonrenewable ones, like oil or gold, are like a limited supply – once we use them up, they're gone forever, and we use a lot of those!

slides.text: Resource distribution shapes the world: The Middle East has roughly 50% of the world's oil reserves — this gives the region enormous economic power. Africa has vast mineral wealth (diamonds, gold, cobalt, coltan). Australia is a major producer of iron ore and coal. Russia has massive natural gas reserves. These resources shape trade, alliances, and conflicts.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how important certain resources are and where they're found. For example, the Middle East has tons of oil, which makes it really powerful. Africa has loads of valuable minerals like diamonds and gold, and Australia is a huge producer of iron and coal. Knowing this helps us understand why countries trade with each other and sometimes even argue.

slides.text: The 'resource curse' is the paradox that countries rich in natural resources are often POORER and less democratic than resource-poor countries. Why? Resource wealth can lead to corruption, conflict over control, neglect of education and other industries, and economic instability when resource prices fall. Countries like Norway have avoided this through careful management.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a really interesting idea called the 'resource curse.' It's kind of weird, but sometimes countries that have tons of natural resources end up being poorer and having more problems, like corruption or fighting, than countries with fewer resources. This happens because it can cause conflict over who controls the wealth, and sometimes governments don't focus on other important things like schools.

slides.prompt: Create an economic resource map: (1) On your world map, use symbols to mark major resources: oil (black dots), coal (brown), gold (yellow), diamonds (blue), iron (red), agricultural land (green shading). (2) Create a key/legend. (3) Identify the top 3 producers of oil, gold, and iron ore. (4) Write a paragraph answering: Why does resource distribution matter for understanding world events? Give 2 specific examples of how resources have affected politics or conflict.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to make our own map! Grab your world map and colored pencils. You'll use symbols like black dots for oil and yellow for gold to mark where these resources are found. Then, make a key so you know what each symbol means. You'll also need to find out which countries produce the most oil, gold, and iron, and then write a short paragraph explaining why all this matters for understanding world events, giving a couple of examples.

slides.text: Resources are the foundation of economics. Understanding where resources are found and who controls them helps explain trade patterns, international relationships, and conflicts throughout history and today.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student distinguish renewable from nonrenewable resources, map major resource-producing regions, and analyze how resources affect economies?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we've learned that natural resources are super important for how countries make money and interact. Understanding where things like oil, minerals, and forests are located really helps explain why countries trade the way they do and why some conflicts happen. You did a great job making your resource map and thinking about these big ideas!

parent_notes: Economic geography connects to current events, history, and environmental science. The resource curse concept is counterintuitive and thought-provoking. Real-world examples: conflicts in the Middle East are partly about oil, cobalt mining in Congo raises ethical questions about electronics manufacturing, and water scarcity drives migration and conflict. Help your child make connections to their daily life: where do the resources in your home come from? The sustainability discussion is increasingly relevant.

title: Number the Stars — Chapters 12-15: Annemarie's Courage
description: Continue reading 'Number the Stars.' Annemarie must make a dangerous journey alone to deliver a crucial packet to Uncle Henrik's boat. Students analyze the climax of the story and discuss how ordinary people find extraordinary courage.
instructions:
1. Review the escape plan and current danger.
2. Read chapters 12-15 aloud.
3. Discuss the climactic scene: Annemarie's run through the dark woods.
4. Analyze how Lowry builds tension through pacing and detail.
5. Discuss the packet's contents and its importance.
6. Connect Annemarie's courage to the larger Danish rescue.
7. Journal reflection on courage and moral responsibility.
8. Discuss the resolution and aftermath.

slides.heading: Number the Stars
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey! This slide is just introducing us to the part of the book we're diving into now. It's called "Number the Stars," and we're going to be reading chapters 12 through 15, which focus on a character named Annemarie and a time when she shows a lot of courage.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare for the climax and conclusion of the book. Have journal ready for writing.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this is our "getting ready" slide. You'll need your "Number the Stars" book, of course, and your reading journal and a pencil to jot down some thoughts. We've also got a map of Denmark and some colored pencils; we might use those to visualize Annemarie's journey later. Make sure you have all these things handy, and maybe ask a grown-up to help you find them if you need to.

slides.text: Today we reach the heart of the story. Annemarie must run alone through the dark forest to the harbor, carrying a packet her mother dropped — a packet that is essential for the refugees' safe passage to Sweden. She is a ten-year-old girl facing Nazi soldiers, darkness, and fear. Everything depends on her.
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is setting the scene for what's about to happen in the story. Annemarie is going to have to do something really brave and dangerous all by herself, carrying something super important for people trying to escape. Imagine being just 10 years old and knowing that everything depends on you – that's the kind of intense moment we're heading into.

slides.text: Read chapters 12-15. Notice how Lowry slows time during the most tense moments. Every footstep, every shadow, every sound is described in detail. This is masterful suspense writing — the reader's heart pounds along with Annemarie's.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is telling us what to do next: read chapters 12 to 15. As you read, pay close attention to how the author describes Annemarie's scary journey. The instructions mention that the author slows down time during the most exciting parts, making you feel like you're right there with her, so keep an eye out for that suspense!

slides.text: After reading, discuss: What was in the packet? (A handkerchief treated with a substance that confuses the dogs the Nazis used to search boats.) This small detail — based on a real historical technique — meant the difference between life and death for the refugees hidden in Uncle Henrik's boat.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is all about a mystery item Annemarie is carrying. After you read, we'll talk about what was actually in that packet and why it was so critical for saving lives. It’s a really clever trick used in real life to help people escape danger, so it’s a super important detail in the story.

slides.text: The title 'Number the Stars' comes from a psalm: 'He counts the number of the stars; He calls them all by name.' Peter, who is part of the Resistance, explains that it means God knows every single person. The Danish rescuers believed that every single life mattered — and they acted on that belief.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a cool bit of background information that connects to the book's title. It explains a saying about God knowing every star by name, and how that idea relates to the Danish people who were helping Jewish families escape. It shows that they believed every single person was important and worth saving, and that's a really powerful message.

slides.prompt: Final book activities: (1) Write a book review of Number the Stars using the review format you learned. Include your honest assessment and recommendation. (2) Compare Annemarie's journey of courage with Milo's journey of learning in The Phantom Tollbooth. How are the two stories alike and different? (3) Research: What happened to Denmark's Jewish community after the war? Did most survive? Write what you find. (4) Write a letter to Annemarie — what would you say to her?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's activity time! You have a few choices here: you can write a review of the whole book, compare Annemarie's bravery to another character you know, do a quick search about what happened in Denmark after the war, or even write a letter to Annemarie herself. Pick one that sounds interesting and work on it for about 25 minutes.

slides.text: Number the Stars teaches us that courage is not the absence of fear but the decision to act despite fear. The Danish rescue saved over 7,000 lives. It happened because ordinary people — fishermen, teachers, parents — decided that their neighbors' lives mattered more than their own safety. This is the highest form of courage.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student analyze the climax of the novel, articulate its themes of courage and moral responsibility, and connect the story to its historical context?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the wrap-up, where we think about what we've learned. The main idea is that being courageous doesn't mean you're not scared; it means you do the right thing even when you are scared. We'll also talk about how the real-life rescue mission in Denmark saved thousands of people because regular folks decided to help their neighbors, which is pretty amazing.

parent_notes: This is the conclusion of a powerful book. Allow time for emotional processing — children may be deeply affected. The historical reality behind the story adds weight: the Danish rescue was one of the most successful civilian resistance operations of WWII. The packet detail (handkerchief to confuse dogs) is historically accurate. Discuss: What qualities did the Danish people have that enabled this rescue? How can we cultivate those qualities? Consider watching a documentary about the Danish rescue together.

title: Narrative Writing — Character Development
description: Students learn to create compelling characters through physical description, dialogue, actions, and inner thoughts. They practice showing character traits through behavior rather than telling, and develop a character for an original narrative.
instructions:
1. Define character development: how characters are revealed and change.
2. Four ways to reveal character: appearance, actions, dialogue, thoughts.
3. Show vs. tell: 'She was brave' (telling) vs. She stepped in front of the younger child (showing).
4. Analyze character development in Number the Stars.
5. Create a character profile sheet.
6. Write a character introduction scene.
7. Practice writing dialogue that reveals character.
8. Plan a character arc: how will the character change?

slides.heading: Character Development
slides.subheading: Bringing People to Life on the Page
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure into making characters for stories! It's telling us that "Character Development" is all about making people in books and movies feel super real, almost like you could meet them. Think of it as learning the secret recipe for creating characters that jump right off the page.

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. You will create a character from scratch today — someone who could star in a story you write.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide is like our "get ready" checklist for today's mission. We've got our language notebook and pencil to write down all our amazing ideas. The character profile template is like a blueprint for building our person, and we'll use books to see how other authors make their characters awesome. Colored pencils might be for adding some flair to our profile later!

slides.text: Characters make stories matter. Without characters we care about, even the most exciting plot falls flat. Today you learn to create characters so real that readers feel they know them personally.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like the "why we're here" talk. It's explaining that characters are the heart of any good story; without them, even a super exciting adventure can feel boring. We're going to learn how to make characters so believable that readers will feel like they're right there with them, sharing their journey.

slides.text: Four tools for revealing character: APPEARANCE (what they look like — but make it meaningful, not just a catalog of features), ACTIONS (what they DO shows who they are), DIALOGUE (how they talk reveals personality, education, emotions), THOUGHTS (inner monologue shows what they think and feel). The best writers use all four.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is giving us the four main tools in our character-building toolbox. We've got how they *look* (appearance), what they *do* (actions), how they *talk* (dialogue), and what they're *thinking* inside their head (thoughts). Great writers use all of these to show us who their characters really are, not just tell us.

slides.text: Show, do not tell: TELLING: 'Marcus was kind.' SHOWING: 'Marcus noticed the new student standing alone at the edge of the field. He jogged over, extending his hand. Hey, I am Marcus. Want to play?' The showing version reveals kindness through ACTION and DIALOGUE without ever using the word.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important trick called "Show, Don't Tell." Instead of just saying "Marcus was kind," we'll show his kindness by describing him *doing* something kind, like inviting someone new to play. This makes the character feel much more real and believable to the reader because they see the kindness in action.

slides.text: Character arc: In good stories, characters CHANGE. Milo went from bored to curious. Annemarie went from uncertain to courageous. Plan your character's arc: Who are they at the beginning? What challenge forces them to grow? Who are they at the end?
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces the idea of a "character arc," which is basically how a character changes and grows throughout a story. Think about how characters in movies sometimes start out scared or unsure but end up brave and confident after facing challenges. We'll learn to plan that kind of journey for our own characters.

slides.prompt: Create a character: (1) Fill out a character profile: name, age, appearance (3 distinctive features), personality traits (3 strengths, 1 flaw), background, greatest fear, greatest hope. (2) Write a scene (10-15 sentences) that INTRODUCES this character without directly stating their traits. Show their personality through actions, dialogue, and one moment of inner thought. (3) Plan their character arc: what challenge will they face and how will they change?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where we get to be creative! We'll fill out a profile for a brand new character, giving them a name, looks, personality, and even hopes and fears. Then, we'll write a short scene to introduce them, showing their personality through their actions and words, and finally, we'll think about how they'll change in our story.

slides.text: The best characters feel as real as people you know. They have strengths and flaws, hopes and fears. When you create a character who feels real, readers invest emotionally — they care about what happens. That is the magic of storytelling.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student create a developed character using showing rather than telling and plan a character arc?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide is like a high-five for a job well done! It reminds us that the best characters feel like real people, with good points and bad points, hopes and worries. When we create characters like that, readers get totally hooked and care about what happens to them, which is the real magic of telling stories.

parent_notes: Character development connects to empathy — imagining how another person thinks and feels. The show-vs-tell distinction is crucial for good writing at any level. When reviewing your child's character scene, ask: 'Can I figure out what this person is like without being told directly?' If the traits come through actions and dialogue, the writing is effective. Encourage your child to base characters on combinations of real people they know — not copies, but inspired by real human traits.

title: Multiplying Mixed Numbers and Whole Numbers by Fractions
description: Students extend fraction multiplication to include mixed numbers and whole number-fraction products. They convert mixed numbers to improper fractions, multiply, and convert back, applying skills to real-world measurement and recipe problems.
instructions:
1. Review fraction multiplication algorithm.
2. Multiplying a whole number by a fraction: 4 × 2/3 = 8/3 = 2 2/3.
3. Multiplying mixed numbers: convert to improper fractions first.
4. Example: 2 1/2 × 1 1/3 = 5/2 × 4/3 = 20/6 = 3 2/6 = 3 1/3.
5. Simplifying before multiplying (cross-canceling) for efficiency.
6. Practice with various problems.
7. Real-world applications: scaling recipes, calculating areas with fractional dimensions.
8. Challenge problems requiring multiple operations.

slides.heading: Multiplying Mixed Numbers
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is introducing us to multiplying mixed numbers, which are numbers like 2 and a half. We've already learned how to multiply regular fractions, and now we're going to build on that to tackle these bigger numbers. It's like leveling up in a game, going from basic moves to more advanced strategies.

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. Review yesterday's fraction multiplication. Have calculator ready for self-checking.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this lesson, we'll need a few things: your math notebook and a pencil to write everything down, fraction strips to help visualize the numbers, and a calculator just for double-checking our answers later. Make sure your notebook is open to a fresh page and you have your calculator handy.

slides.text: Whole number times a fraction: 4 × 2/3 means 4 groups of 2/3. Write 4 as 4/1. Now multiply: (4×2)/(1×3) = 8/3 = 2 2/3. Check: is 2 2/3 less than 4? Yes, because 2/3 is less than 1, so 4 groups of 2/3 is less than 4 groups of 1.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step shows us how to multiply a whole number by a fraction, like having 4 groups of 2/3. Think of it like having 4 bags, and each bag has 2/3 of a cookie inside. To figure out how many cookies you have in total, you first write the whole number 4 as a fraction (4/1) and then multiply straight across. You end up with 8/3, which is the same as 2 whole cookies and 2/3 of another cookie.

slides.text: Mixed numbers: Always convert to improper fractions FIRST. Example: 2 1/2 × 1 1/3. Convert: 2 1/2 = 5/2, and 1 1/3 = 4/3. Now multiply: (5×4)/(2×3) = 20/6. Simplify: 20/6 = 3 2/6 = 3 1/3. Done!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, when we multiply mixed numbers, like 2 and a half times 1 and a third, the trick is to turn them into improper fractions first. So, 2 and a half becomes 5/2, and 1 and a third becomes 4/3. Once they're both improper fractions, we just multiply them like we learned before, and then convert the answer back into a mixed number if we want.

slides.text: Shortcut — cross-canceling: Before multiplying, you can simplify across the multiplication. Example: 3/4 × 2/9. Instead of getting 6/36 and then simplifying, notice that 3 and 9 share a factor of 3 (cancel to 1 and 3), and 2 and 4 share a factor of 2 (cancel to 1 and 2). Now multiply: 1/2 × 1/3 = 1/6. Same answer, less work!
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces a super handy shortcut called "cross-canceling" that makes multiplying fractions way faster. Instead of multiplying everything out and then simplifying a big fraction, you can actually simplify numbers *across* the multiplication sign *before* you multiply. It's like finding a secret passage that gets you to the answer quicker, and it really helps when the numbers get large.

slides.text: Real-world application: A room is 10 1/2 feet by 8 2/3 feet. What is the area? Convert: 21/2 × 26/3 = 546/6 = 91 square feet. Or: A recipe serves 4 and calls for 1 2/3 cups flour. How much for 6 servings? That is 1.5 times the recipe: 3/2 × 5/3 = 15/6 = 2 1/2 cups.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here we see how this math applies to real life! Imagine you're figuring out the size of a room or how much flour you need for a bigger batch of cookies. We can use multiplying mixed numbers to calculate things like area or scale up recipes, so it's super useful for cooking and building projects.

slides.prompt: Solve these: (1) 5 × 3/4 (2) 3/5 × 2 1/2 (3) 1 3/4 × 2 2/3 (4) 3 1/3 × 1 1/2 (5) 4 1/4 × 2/3 (6) Use cross-canceling: 5/6 × 3/10 (7) Recipe: calls for 2 1/4 cups for 8 servings. How much for 12 servings? (8) A rectangular garden is 6 3/4 meters by 4 2/3 meters. Find the area. (9) A sweater pattern calls for 3 1/2 yards of yarn per row. How much yarn for 2 1/2 rows?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to practice what we've learned! You'll solve a bunch of problems, some with whole numbers and fractions, some with mixed numbers, and a couple that are real-world scenarios like adjusting a recipe or finding the area of a garden. Use the cross-canceling shortcut where you can to make it easier, and don't forget to check your answers with the calculator.

slides.text: You can now multiply any combination of fractions, whole numbers, and mixed numbers. Cross-canceling saves time. These skills are used in cooking, building, sewing, and any field that uses measurements.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student multiply mixed numbers and whole numbers by fractions, simplify using cross-canceling, and solve real-world problems?
slides.mascot_explanation: Awesome job! You've successfully learned how to multiply all sorts of fractions, including whole numbers and mixed numbers, and you even mastered the cross-canceling shortcut. Think about how cool it is that you can now figure out things like scaling recipes or calculating measurements for projects just by using these math skills.

parent_notes: Mixed number multiplication comes up constantly in real life — recipes, building projects, fabric calculations. The key step is converting to improper fractions first. Cross-canceling is an efficiency technique that reduces the size of numbers you work with. If your child finds it confusing, it is perfectly fine to multiply first and simplify after. The recipe scaling problem is practical — have your child actually scale a recipe for dinner.

title: Food Chains — Energy Flow in Ecosystems
description: Students learn how energy flows through ecosystems via food chains. They identify producers, consumers, and decomposers, understand trophic levels, and trace energy from the sun through multiple organisms.
instructions:
1. Review ecosystem basics from week 13.
2. All energy in ecosystems starts with the SUN.
3. Producers (plants) capture solar energy through photosynthesis.
4. Consumers eat producers or other consumers: primary, secondary, tertiary.
5. Decomposers break down dead organisms, recycling nutrients.
6. Build food chains for different ecosystems.
7. Introduce the 10% rule: only 10% of energy passes to the next level.
8. Students create illustrated food chains for 3 different ecosystems.

slides.heading: Food Chains
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing what we're going to learn about: food chains and how energy moves around in nature, like a big, connected system. It's basically the story of who eats whom and where all that energy comes from.

slides.setup_instructions: Open science notebook. Have colored pencils ready for detailed food chain illustrations.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, you'll need your science notebook, some colored pencils, a regular pencil, any notes you have about different ecosystems, and a big piece of paper for drawing. Make sure your notebook is open and your colored pencils are handy so you're ready to draw some awesome food chains later.

slides.text: Every ecosystem runs on energy from the SUN. PRODUCERS (plants, algae) capture this solar energy through photosynthesis and convert it to food (glucose). This is the foundation of almost all life on Earth. Without producers, there would be no food for anything else.
slides.mascot_explanation: So, think about where you get your energy – from food, right? Well, plants are super special because they make their OWN food using sunlight, which is why they're called producers. This slide is telling us that all the energy in any ecosystem, whether it's a forest or the ocean, starts with the sun, and plants are the first ones to grab that energy.

slides.text: CONSUMERS eat other organisms for energy: PRIMARY consumers eat producers (herbivores: rabbit eats grass), SECONDARY consumers eat primary consumers (carnivores: fox eats rabbit), TERTIARY consumers eat secondary consumers (eagle eats fox). DECOMPOSERS (fungi, bacteria) break down dead organisms and recycle nutrients back into the soil.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we meet all the eaters! Consumers are anything that can't make its own food, so they have to eat something else. We've got primary consumers that munch on plants, secondary consumers that eat the plant-eaters, and even tertiary consumers that eat the secondary ones – like a snake eating a mouse that ate seeds. Then there are decomposers, which are like nature's clean-up crew, breaking down dead stuff.

slides.text: A food chain shows the path of energy: Sun → Grass → Rabbit → Fox → Eagle → Decomposers. Arrows point in the direction of ENERGY FLOW (from eaten to eater). Each step is a TROPHIC LEVEL. Energy is lost at each level — mostly as heat from the organisms' life processes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine a line of dominoes falling – that's kind of like a food chain! This slide shows how energy travels from one living thing to another. The arrows always point from the organism being eaten to the one that's eating it, showing us where the energy is going. Each spot in that chain is called a trophic level, and it's important to remember that energy gets a little bit lost at every single step.

slides.text: The 10% Rule: Only about 10% of energy at one trophic level passes to the next. If grass captures 10,000 units of energy, the rabbit gets about 1,000, the fox gets about 100, and the eagle gets about 10. This explains why there are far more producers than top predators — there simply is not enough energy to support many top predators.
slides.mascot_explanation: This might sound a little strange, but only about 10% of the energy from one level actually makes it to the next level. So, if plants have a ton of energy from the sun, the animals that eat them only get a small piece of that energy pie, and the animals that eat *those* animals get an even smaller piece. This is why you see way more bugs than lions in the wild!

slides.prompt: Create detailed, illustrated food chains for 3 ecosystems: (1) FOREST: identify at least 4 organisms at different trophic levels. (2) OCEAN: from phytoplankton to a top predator. (3) GRASSLAND: from grass to a top predator. For each: draw and label each organism, show arrows indicating energy flow, label the trophic level (producer, primary/secondary/tertiary consumer), and include decomposers. Then answer: Why are there always fewer top predators than prey animals?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is the fun part where you get to be creative! You'll pick three different places, like a forest, the ocean, and a grassland, and draw a food chain for each one. Make sure to draw and label all the plants and animals, show the energy going the right way with arrows, label what kind of consumer they are, and don't forget the decomposers! Then, think about why there are always fewer animals at the top of the food chain.

slides.text: Food chains reveal the hidden connections in nature. Every organism depends on others for energy. The 10% rule explains why ecosystems are shaped like pyramids: many producers, fewer herbivores, and very few top predators. Remove any link and the whole chain is affected.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student construct food chains with correct trophic levels and explain the 10% energy transfer rule?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, we've just learned that everything in nature is connected by energy, kind of like a giant web. Food chains show us this flow, and the 10% rule helps explain why there are usually lots of plants, fewer plant-eaters, and even fewer top predators, making ecosystems look like pyramids. You did a great job building these food chains and understanding how energy moves!

parent_notes: Food chains make abstract ecology concrete. Children often enjoy tracing the path of energy from sun to top predator. The 10% rule is powerful because it explains observable patterns: why there are millions of grasshoppers but only a few eagles. Extend the learning: what food chains lead to YOUR dinner? Trace a meal back to its solar energy source. The decomposer role is important and often overlooked — without decomposers, dead material would pile up and nutrients would not recycle.

title: Renaissance Art Preview — Giotto and the Break from Medieval Style
description: Students study Giotto di Bondone as the artist who bridged medieval and Renaissance art. They compare his three-dimensional, emotional figures with the flat, symbolic style of earlier medieval art, marking the beginning of a revolution in how humans depicted the world.
instructions:
1. Review medieval art characteristics: flat, symbolic, gold backgrounds, stylized figures.
2. Introduce Giotto (1267-1337): the artist who changed everything.
3. Compare a medieval painting with Giotto's work: emotional expression, 3D space, naturalism.
4. Discuss what made Giotto revolutionary: he painted people that LOOKED like real people.
5. Key works: Scrovegni Chapel frescoes.
6. Students practice drawing figures showing emotion and depth.
7. Compare Giotto's influence on later Renaissance artists.
8. Create a before/after comparison: medieval style vs. Giotto style.
materials_needed: Reference images of medieval and Giotto's art

slides.heading: Giotto
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our whole art adventure. It's introducing us to a super important artist named Giotto, and it's calling him "The Dawn of Renaissance Art." Think of it like saying he was the first light of a new day for art, showing us the way to a whole new style.

slides.setup_instructions: Look up images of Byzantine/medieval art and Giotto's Scrovegni Chapel frescoes for side-by-side comparison. Set out drawing materials.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need to get our art supplies ready! You've got drawing paper, a pencil, and colored pencils for making your art pop. The reference images are like cheat sheets – we'll look at some old medieval art and some of Giotto's cool paintings so we can see the difference. And an eraser is always good to have, just in case.

slides.text: Medieval art served a specific purpose: teaching religious stories to people who could not read. It used SYMBOLS rather than realism. Figures were flat, stiff, and had identical expressions. Gold backgrounds symbolized heaven. Size indicated importance, not perspective. It was beautiful but intentionally unrealistic.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is about understanding what art was like *before* Giotto. Back then, art was mostly used to teach stories from the Bible to people who couldn't read, so it wasn't trying to look real. Think of it like a comic strip where the pictures are mostly symbols, not like actual people or places. The figures were flat, and everything was very stiff and serious, with gold backgrounds to make it look heavenly.

slides.text: Then came Giotto di Bondone (c.1267-1337), a Florentine painter who did something revolutionary: he painted people who LOOKED like real people. His figures had weight, volume, and emotion. They stood in recognizable spaces. They expressed joy, grief, anger, and love. For the first time in Western art, painted people felt ALIVE.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is where Giotto comes in and totally shakes things up! He was an artist who decided people should look like *people* in paintings, not just flat symbols. His figures had shape and weight, like they were actually standing there, and you could see real feelings on their faces – sadness, happiness, all of it! It was like his paintings suddenly came to life.

slides.text: Compare: a medieval Madonna (flat, symmetrical, serene, gold background) with Giotto's Lamentation (figures hunched in grief, real landscape, dramatic emotion, overlapping bodies creating depth). The difference is stunning. Giotto did not just change style — he changed what art was FOR: from symbolic teaching to emotional experience.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is asking us to really *look* at the difference. We'll compare a typical medieval painting, which is flat and peaceful, with one of Giotto's scenes, like "The Lamentation," where people are really showing their grief. You'll see how Giotto's art made you *feel* something, not just look at a symbol.

slides.text: Drawing with emotion: Medieval artists drew the same face for every person. Giotto made each face unique and expressive. Practice: draw the same face showing 4 different emotions: joy, sadness, surprise, anger. Change the eyebrows, mouth, and eyes. Then practice drawing a figure with WEIGHT — standing firmly on the ground, not floating.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we get to practice being artists who understand feelings! Giotto made his characters show real emotions, so we're going to try that too. Grab your pencil and draw the same face four times, but make each one show a different feeling – happy, sad, surprised, and angry – by changing the eyes and mouth. Then, try drawing a person standing so they look like they have weight, like they're really on the ground.

slides.prompt: Create a comparison piece: on one half of your paper, draw a scene in MEDIEVAL STYLE (flat figures, gold or simple background, stiff poses, minimal emotion). On the other half, draw the SAME scene in GIOTTO'S STYLE (figures with volume and weight, emotional expressions, a realistic setting with depth). The scene can be anything: people meeting, a feast, a landscape with figures. Label both sides and write a paragraph explaining the differences.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to create something awesome! On your paper, you're going to draw the same scene twice. First, draw it in that old medieval style we talked about – flat, stiff figures, maybe a gold background. Then, on the other half, redraw that exact same scene, but this time in Giotto's style, with people who look real and have emotions, and a background that looks like a real place.

slides.text: Giotto planted the seed of the Renaissance 150 years before it fully bloomed. His idea — that art should represent the real world and real human emotions — changed the course of Western art forever. Every realistic painting, photograph, and movie owes something to this medieval Florentine painter.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student identify the key differences between medieval and proto-Renaissance art and demonstrate them in their own drawings?
slides.mascot_explanation: This last slide tells us why Giotto is such a big deal. He was like the very first spark that started the whole Renaissance art movement, which lasted for hundreds of years! His idea that art should show the real world and real feelings is something we still see in movies and pictures today, all thanks to him.

parent_notes: The comparison between medieval and Renaissance art styles is visually dramatic and easy to understand. Looking at actual examples online is essential for this lesson. Giotto is considered the 'father of Western painting' and his innovations (perspective, emotion, naturalism) laid the groundwork for everything that followed. The comparison drawing activity makes the differences tangible. This connects to the Renaissance history content coming in week 16.

title: Organizational Systems — Managing Long-Term Projects
description: Students learn to break large projects into manageable steps, create timelines with milestones, and track progress using project management techniques. They apply these skills to plan an actual multi-week project of their choosing.
instructions:
1. Discuss why long-term projects fail: poor planning, procrastination, overwhelm.
2. Introduce project management basics: define goal, break into steps, set deadlines.
3. Teach backward planning: start from the due date and work backward.
4. Create a Gantt chart (visual timeline of tasks).
5. Discuss milestones: checkpoints to verify progress.
6. Students choose a personal project and create a management plan.
7. Build in buffer time for unexpected delays.
8. Review and refine the plan.

slides.heading: Project Management
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is all about "Project Management," which is basically a fancy way of saying how to plan and get big things done without feeling totally overwhelmed. It's like having a map for a really long journey so you know where you're going and how to get there.

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. Have a calendar visible for timeline planning. Large paper for creating a visual project plan.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this next part, we need some tools to get our planning done. We've got a notebook and pencil for writing things down, a ruler to make neat lines, colored pencils to make our plans look cool and easy to read, a calendar to keep track of dates, and some large paper to draw out our whole plan. Go grab these things with a grown-up so we're ready to go!

slides.text: Big projects become manageable when broken into small steps. A research paper, a science fair project, building a model, or learning a new skill — all require planning. People who succeed at big projects are not smarter or more talented; they are better PLANNERS.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is telling us that the biggest secret to finishing huge projects, like building a giant Lego castle or writing a whole book, is to break them down into super tiny, manageable steps. It's like eating a giant cookie – you don't try to swallow it all at once, right? You take small bites, and planning does the same thing for big projects.

slides.text: Step 1: Define the GOAL clearly. Not 'do a project about animals' but 'create a 10-page illustrated field guide to local birds by March 15.' Step 2: List EVERY step needed to reach the goal. Step 3: ESTIMATE how long each step will take. Step 4: Assign DEADLINES. Step 5: Identify MILESTONES (checkpoints for progress). Step 6: Add BUFFER TIME (things always take longer than expected).
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's where we get into the nitty-gritty of planning! First, you need to know exactly what you want to achieve – not just "learn guitar," but "learn to play three songs on the guitar by summer." Then, you list out every single little thing you need to do, guess how long each will take, set dates for when things need to be done, pick checkpoints to see how you're doing, and always add extra time just in case!

slides.text: Backward planning: Start from the deadline and work backward. If the project is due in 4 weeks, and the last step (final presentation) needs 2 days, then everything else must be done by 3 days before. Work backward for each step. This prevents the common mistake of spending too long on early steps and rushing at the end.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super smart trick called "backward planning." Instead of starting from today and going forward, you look at your final deadline and work your way backward, figuring out when each step needs to be finished so you don't run out of time at the end. It's like planning a surprise party – you figure out when the party is, then when the invitations need to go out, then when you need to buy decorations, working backward from the big day.

slides.text: A GANTT chart is a visual timeline showing tasks as horizontal bars across a calendar. Each bar shows when a task starts and ends. Overlapping bars show tasks happening simultaneously. It gives you a clear picture of the entire project at a glance. Professional project managers use these for everything from building bridges to launching software.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide introduces a Gantt chart, which sounds complicated but is really just a cool visual timeline. Imagine a calendar where you draw colored bars showing exactly when each task for your project starts and when it finishes; it gives you a clear picture of everything at once, like seeing the whole movie's plot laid out.

slides.prompt: Choose a real multi-week project you want to complete (examples: write a short story, build a model castle, learn 10 recorder songs, complete a nature journal, plan a family event, create a coding project). (1) Define the goal specifically. (2) List all steps needed. (3) Estimate time for each step. (4) Use backward planning to set deadlines. (5) Create a simple Gantt chart. (6) Identify 3 milestones. (7) Add buffer time. Present your plan to your family.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is where you get to be the project manager for something *you* want to do! Pick a cool project, like building a birdhouse or learning a new video game skill, and then follow the steps on the screen: define your goal super clearly, list all the steps, figure out how long each takes, use backward planning for deadlines, draw a simple Gantt chart, pick three important checkpoints, and add some extra time. Then, show your awesome plan to your family!

slides.text: Project management is a life skill used by architects, engineers, business leaders, filmmakers, and anyone who accomplishes big things. The secret is not willpower — it is planning. A good plan turns an overwhelming goal into a series of simple steps. Start using these skills now and big projects will never intimidate you.
slides.mastery_check: Did the student create a realistic project management plan with defined steps, deadlines, milestones, and a visual timeline?
slides.mascot_explanation: So, the big takeaway is that planning isn't just for grown-ups with boring jobs; it's how *anyone* accomplishes amazing things, from building skyscrapers to making movies. By breaking down big goals into small, planned steps, those overwhelming projects become totally doable, and you'll feel way more confident tackling them.

parent_notes: Project management skills transfer to every area of life: school assignments, personal goals, household projects, and eventually careers. Help your child follow through on their chosen project — the planning is only valuable if connected to execution. Check in weekly on their progress against the timeline. If they fall behind, help them adjust the plan rather than abandon it. The Gantt chart is a real professional tool — introducing it now gives your child a significant advantage.

title: Narrative Writing — Dialogue and Voice
description: Students learn to write effective dialogue that sounds natural, reveals character, and advances the plot. They study dialogue punctuation, attribution tags, and the art of giving each character a distinctive voice.
instructions:
1. Review character development from Day 2.
2. Teach dialogue punctuation: quotation marks, commas, capitals, paragraphing.
3. Discuss attribution tags: 'said' is not boring — it is invisible (good!).
4. Practice: Show personality through dialogue without attribution.
5. Each character should sound different based on age, personality, education.
6. Dialogue should reveal information and advance the story.
7. Students write a dialogue scene between two characters.
8. Read dialogue aloud to test if it sounds natural.

slides.heading: Dialogue
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our lesson on dialogue, which is just a fancy word for characters talking in a story. It's telling us that the goal is to learn how to make our characters' conversations sound real and interesting, helping us make them come alive for the reader.

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. Find dialogue scenes in your current or recent books for analysis.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, so this slide lists the things we'll need for our writing adventure today. We've got our language notebook and pencil for writing, some books to find examples of good talking in stories, and colored pencils to maybe make our notes look cool. Grab these things, and then find a book you're reading or just finished and flip to a part with people talking.

slides.text: Dialogue brings characters to life. When characters SPEAK, readers hear their voices, feel their emotions, and learn about their relationships. But writing good dialogue is harder than it looks — it must sound natural while doing real work in the story.
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is explaining *why* talking in stories is so important. It's not just about filling up space; when characters speak, we get to hear their personality, how they're feeling, and what their relationships are like, all through their words. Good dialogue makes the story feel much more alive and real.

slides.text: Punctuation rules: (1) Quotation marks around spoken words: 'I am coming,' she said. (2) Comma before the closing quote if followed by attribution: 'Wait for me,' he called. (3) Period inside quotes if no attribution follows: 'This is the place.' (4) NEW PARAGRAPH for each new speaker. (5) Capital letter to start the spoken sentence.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a super important slide about the secret codes of writing dialogue correctly – the punctuation! We need to put quotation marks around the exact words characters say, use commas and periods in specific spots, make sure the first word of what they say is capitalized, and start a new line every time a different person talks. It looks like a lot, but it's just a set of rules to follow.

slides.text: Attribution tags: 'Said' is the best all-purpose tag because readers barely notice it — it is invisible. Avoid fancy replacements like 'ejaculated' or 'exclaimed' unless the emotion truly requires it. Better approach: use actions instead of tags. 'Marcus kicked the dirt. I don\'t want to go.' We know Marcus is speaking without being told.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're talking about those little phrases that tell us who is speaking, like "he said" or "she asked." This slide tells us that "said" is actually a really great word because it's so plain that we don't even notice it, letting the character's words shine. It suggests using actions, like "He sighed," instead of fancy words to show who's talking sometimes.

slides.text: Give each character a distinctive voice: A knight might speak formally ('My liege, I shall fulfill this duty.'). A merchant might speak quickly and practically ('Two gold coins. Take it or leave it.'). A child might speak with simple directness ('But why can\'t I come?'). If you cover the attribution tags, can you still tell who is speaking? That is the test.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is all about giving each character their own unique voice, like how your friends might sound totally different from each other. We'll learn to make a knight sound like a knight and a kid sound like a kid, using their words to show who they are without always needing to say who's talking. The challenge is to see if you can tell who's speaking just by *how* they say things.

slides.prompt: Write a dialogue scene (15-20 lines of dialogue) between two characters with contrasting personalities. They are discussing a disagreement or making a plan. Requirements: (1) Correct punctuation throughout. (2) Each character has a distinctive voice — could you tell them apart without tags? (3) The dialogue reveals something about both characters. (4) The conversation advances a plot (something changes by the end). (5) Use at least 2 action beats instead of attribution tags. Read it aloud when finished — does it sound like real people talking?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, this is our main writing challenge! You're going to write a conversation between two characters who don't agree on something or are planning something. Make sure you use all the punctuation rules we learned, give them different ways of talking so you can tell them apart, and make sure their conversation reveals something about them and moves the story forward. After you write it, read it out loud to see if it sounds like real people chatting.

slides.text: Great dialogue does three things at once: it reveals character, provides information, and moves the story forward. If your dialogue is not doing at least two of these, it needs revision. Listen to how real people talk — the rhythms, the interruptions, the unfinished sentences — and bring that authenticity to your writing.
slides.mastery_check: Can the student write correctly punctuated dialogue that sounds natural, reveals character, and advances the story?
slides.mascot_explanation: This final slide is a reminder of what makes dialogue awesome: it should show us who the characters are, give us information, and push the story along, all at the same time. Think about how people *actually* talk, with their own rhythms and sometimes even talking over each other, and try to capture that realness in your writing. You've learned how to make characters speak, and that's a huge step in making your stories amazing!

parent_notes: Dialogue writing is a skill that takes practice. The punctuation rules are specific and important — they become automatic with practice. The read-aloud test is essential: if dialogue sounds stiff or unnatural when spoken, it needs revision. Encourage your child to listen to how different people speak — word choice, sentence length, formality level all differ by person. The 'no attribution test' (can you tell who is speaking?) is a powerful quality check.

title: Dividing Fractions — Conceptual Understanding
description: Students discover the meaning of fraction division through real-world contexts and visual models. They learn the 'invert and multiply' rule but understand WHY it works, using measurement division problems and the relationship between multiplication and division.
instructions:
1. Present the problem: How many 1/4-cup servings are in 3 cups? (Answer: 12)
2. This is division: 3 ÷ 1/4 = 12.
3. Pattern discovery: dividing by a fraction gives a LARGER answer.
4. Visual model: how many 1/3s fit in 2?
5. Introduce the algorithm: invert the second fraction and multiply (keep-change-flip).
6. Explain WHY it works: dividing by 1/4 is the same as multiplying by 4.
7. Practice with various problems.
8. Word problems involving fraction division.

slides.heading: Dividing Fractions
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is just introducing our topic: dividing fractions. It’s a big deal because it’s like a puzzle asking "how many of this smaller fraction piece can we fit into a bigger amount?" Think about cutting a cake – you’re figuring out how many slices you can get.

slides.setup_instructions: Open notebook. Set out fraction strips. If you have measuring cups, they are great for demonstrating fraction division.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this slide, we need our math notebook and pencil to write things down, and our fraction strips are super helpful for actually seeing how fractions fit together. If you have measuring cups, those are awesome for visualizing this stuff, so grab those too if you can!

slides.text: Here is a question: If you have 3 cups of juice and each serving is 1/4 cup, how many servings do you have? Use measuring cups or draw it: 3 cups, each divided into fourths, gives 12 quarter-cups. So 3 ÷ 1/4 = 12. Notice: dividing by a fraction gives a BIGGER answer. This makes sense — smaller pieces means more pieces!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our first example, showing how to figure out how many quarter-cup servings are in 3 cups of juice. Imagine you have 3 big cups of juice and you want to pour it into smaller quarter-cup glasses. You’d end up with a lot more glasses than you started with, right? That’s why dividing by a fraction like 1/4 actually makes the answer bigger, which is kind of cool and different from dividing whole numbers.

slides.text: More examples with models: How many 1/3s fit in 2? Draw 2 wholes, divide each into thirds: 6 pieces. So 2 ÷ 1/3 = 6. How many 1/2s fit in 3/4? Draw 3/4 of a whole, see how many 1/2s fit: 1 1/2. So 3/4 ÷ 1/2 = 1 1/2. Check with strips.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're looking at more examples to really get the hang of it. We're asking how many thirds fit into 2, or how many halves fit into three-quarters of a pizza. The best way to understand this is to draw it out, like dividing up your shapes, or use those fraction strips to see exactly how many of the smaller pieces fit inside the bigger one.

slides.text: The algorithm (Keep-Change-Flip): 3 ÷ 1/4: KEEP the first number (3/1), CHANGE division to multiplication (×), FLIP the second fraction (4/1). Result: 3/1 × 4/1 = 12/1 = 12. Same answer! The rule: to divide by a fraction, multiply by its RECIPROCAL (flipped version).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn a neat trick called "Keep-Change-Flip" to solve fraction division problems super fast. You keep the first fraction the same, change the division sign to multiplication, and flip the second fraction upside down. So, 3 divided by 1/4 becomes 3 times 4, which is way easier!

slides.text: Why does Keep-Change-Flip work? Dividing by 1/4 means 'how many quarter-pieces?' Multiplying by 4 means 'four times as many pieces.' These are the SAME thing! Dividing by 1/2 is the same as multiplying by 2. Dividing by 2/3 is the same as multiplying by 3/2. The reciprocal reverses the fraction's effect.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide explains *why* that Keep-Change-Flip trick works. When you divide by a tiny fraction like 1/4, you're basically asking how many of those small pieces fit into your amount, and it turns out to be the same as multiplying by the whole number 4. It's like saying "how many groups of 1/4 are in 3?" is the same as asking "what’s 4 times 3?".

slides.prompt: Solve these using Keep-Change-Flip AND check at least 3 with models: (1) 4 ÷ 1/3 (2) 2 ÷ 1/5 (3) 3/4 ÷ 1/4 (4) 5/6 ÷ 1/3 (5) 2/3 ÷ 1/6 (6) 1/2 ÷ 3/4 Word problems: (7) You have 6 cups of flour. Each batch of cookies uses 3/4 cup. How many batches? (8) A rope is 5/8 meter long. You cut pieces that are 1/8 meter each. How many pieces? (9) A recipe makes 3/4 of a pan. How many recipes to fill 3 pans?
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's time to try it yourself! You'll use the Keep-Change-Flip method for these problems, but also try drawing them out or using your fraction strips for at least three of them to really see what's happening. Don't worry if a word problem seems tricky, just break it down like we did with the juice example.
